We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators has an initial object, which is unique up to canonical isomorphism. This provides a foundation for quantum theory based on purely categorical methods. The uniqueness result is a special case of a more general theorem about the initial object of a symmetric monoidal closed category with certain extra structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, and show that myxozoans are a sister group to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism and the origin of the parasitic lifestyle. (Read more)

COVID-19 is a disease that has caused a global pandemic and has resulted in millions of deaths. The disease is caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) virus, which is able to evade the host immune response by blocking the action of interferon (IFN). In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which SARS-CoV-2 is able to hijack the Nup98-Rae1 complex to block nuclear import of ISGs. Our findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the pandemic. This study provides a detailed description of the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the Hv1 channel. This information will be useful for future drug development for Hv1 channels.

We show that the variability of global maize production will increase substantially as the world warms, and that this increase will be much larger than the increase in mean yields. This will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year, and will make the world’s major maize-exporting countries much more vulnerable to climate variability. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance, and they highlight the importance of food security in the context of climate change.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant LMH species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. Our results suggest that the extent of food-resource partitioning among LMH is greater than previously thought, and that the degree of food-resource partitioning is linked to the body size of the species. These results have implications for understanding the role of LMH in African savanna biodiversity.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the survey also reveals substantial uncertainty about the length of the crisis, which is a key determinant of business survival. Moreover, many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, we find that many small businesses plan to apply for the CARES Act programs, but many anticipate problems accessing the funds.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the marine environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is much less than expected, and that the majority of it is concentrated in convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. This distribution is mostly the result of a size-selective sink, which involves the fragmentation of plastic debris into smaller particles, their transfer to the ocean interior, and the accumulation of these particles in the deep sea. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris, and of the importance of this pollution in the ocean. It also highlights the need for further research to resolve the nature and the significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important and debated topics in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where life exists. The solar system is also the only place in the universe where we can study the origin of the solar system.

We provide a comprehensive picture of the evolution of the global fishing fleet over the last 70 y. We show that the global fleet has doubled in size, and the motorized fleet has increased by a factor of 10. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased by a fifth since 1950, but this trend is not uniform across the world. We also show that the global fleet is aging, and the number of small vessels is increasing. We conclude that the global fleet is likely to continue to grow, but the rate of expansion is slowing.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also one of the most plastic. We show that the ability to reproduce is plastic in a way that increases the reproductive output of the mother.

This study provides proof of concept for the potential of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to slow down the progression of synucleinopathies, in particular multiple system atrophy (MSA). This study is of particular interest because it is the first to show that the drug is able to reduce the load of α-syn in the brain of a mouse model of MSA. This is a major step forward in the development of a therapeutic approach for this devastating disease.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues. It is the primary regulator of blood flow, inflammation, and clotting. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells and is the only cell type in the body that is in direct contact with the blood. The endothelium is able to communicate with other cells in the body and is able to respond to a wide variety of stimuli. This paper describes the structure of the endothelium and the communication network that it uses to control the body.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to monitor and respond to the pandemic. However, the data are often difficult to access and use. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. The data are available through a common interface, allowing researchers to easily combine and analyze them. We demonstrate that the data can be used to monitor the pandemic, and to augment traditional public health reporting. The data and software are available to the public at no cost. We hope that this will help to empower researchers and decision makers to respond to the pandemic.

This work provides a structural and functional explanation for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. It also provides a structural basis for the lack of C-type inactivation in the KcsA-T75A mutant.

This study is the first to characterize the natural products of anaerobic gut fungi. The results provide a foundation for the discovery of novel natural products, as well as a resource for the study of the biosynthesis of natural products.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats and that this effect is mediated by the brain region the nucleus accumbens. We further identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens in the development of a subordinate status and in the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work is about the design of mechanical structures that can be used to create a wide range of mechanical devices. The design is based on the synthesis of composite structures that are composed of multiple materials. The materials are chosen to be able to produce the desired response. The structures are then manufactured using multimaterial fabrication. The response of the fabricated structures is then demonstrated in experiments.

This study provides evidence for a role of IGF2BP1 in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. This is of interest for the understanding of the role of this protein in the development of hemoglobin expression in humans and for the development of strategies to influence hemoglobin expression in the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of resistance to treatment is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to treatment that is common in many cancers, and that may be overcome by combination therapy.
This study provides a mechanism of action of the major class of antihypertensive drugs, which is of interest to the general public and the scientific community.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of older forest-associated bird species, but that the policy has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of these species. Our results suggest that the NWFP has not been successful in halting the decline of early-seral-associated bird species, and that the policy has not yet been successful in reversing this decline. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be extended to the design of new antibiotics for other classes of antibiotics. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics to combat the growing threat of antibiotic resistance.

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful in many image-processing problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful to the machine-learning community and will be widely adopted in practice.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish is a classic example of the impact of environmental change on biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We show that the evolution of the fish was shaped by the impact of climate change on the lake system.

This study shows that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has a negative impact on sleep. This is the first study to show that the use of electronic devices suppresses melatonin, which is the hormone that is responsible for the onset of sleep. This study also shows that the use of electronic devices phase-delays the circadian clock, which is the biological process that is responsible for the timing of sleep. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known climatic event that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the event. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Os in bulk samples and magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is likely terrestrial, and that the Os in the magnetic grains/microspherules is also likely terrestrial. The Os in the magnetic grains/microspherules is likely derived from the impact of a bolide 12.9 ka ago.
This study provides a comprehensive view of the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system, which is essential for the development of a number of autoimmune diseases.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of beetles, their evolution, and the role of herbivory in their diversification remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles, including the evolution of genes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls, using the most comprehensive dataset of its kind. Our results provide insights into the evolution of beetles, including the origin of the order, the diversification of herbivores, and the role of plant cell walls in beetle evolution.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We show that the size of the population does not enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of technology. We also show that the size of the population does not enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of technology when the population is large.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apoE allele, APOE4. APOE is a major component of the classical complement cascade and is highly expressed in the brain. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of a complement component, C1q, in the brain, which may contribute to the increased vulnerability of senescent synapses to complement-mediated neurodegeneration in APOE4. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased risk of stroke.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is about 1,200 km in radius and has a density of 12.0 g/cm3. It is the densest part of the Earth and is the only part of the Earth that is not in hydrostatic equilibrium. The inner core is a mystery because of its origin and structure. In this paper, we propose a new mechanism for the formation of the inner core and provide a solution to the paradox of the inner core.

This study provides evidence that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings are consistent with the notion that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation is a key factor in the development of addiction.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. Here, we use a state-of-the-art class of deep learning models to study the brain and language. We find that the most powerful models predict nearly 100% of the explainable variance in the brain responses of normal human participants performing a language task. These results provide computational evidence for the fundamental role of predictive processing in the human language system. They also suggest that the brain’s uniquely human language system may be optimized for predicting the next word in a sentence. This hypothesis can now be tested with direct language production and comprehension experiments. Such experiments are crucial for advancing our understanding of the human language system. They are also essential for developing computational models of language that can be used to study, and potentially treat, language disorders.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability is not intrinsic to DL, but rather is a consequence of the fact that DL is a generalization of well-established numerical methods. We show that there are well-conditioned problems in numerical analysis where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there is no algorithm that can train such a NN. This result implies a classification theory of the conditions under which one can compute stable NNs.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the lack of a vaccine, and the failure of people to take the necessary precautions. In this context, it is important to understand the psychology of the general public, and in particular, to understand why people do not follow the rules. This study shows that the classic experiment by Festinger and Carlsmith is still relevant today, and that it provides a valuable insight into the psychology of the general public.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it is still with us today. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are very similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions. This suggests that they are still able to cause disease, and that they have not lost the ability to cause disease.

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum and statistical mechanics. They are the basis of the description of the quantum state, and they are the key ingredients of the quantum resources used in quantum information processing. The evolution of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a fundamental problem, which has been studied for a long time. However, it was only recently that a complete description of the evolution of entanglement in interacting systems was achieved. This work provides a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, and it opens the door to the study of the dynamics of other physical quantities.

This study describes the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a recoded version of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, which is expected to be more immunogenic than the wild-type spike protein. The vaccine candidate is also temperature sensitive, which is expected to facilitate its large-scale manufacturing. The vaccine candidate was shown to be protective in a relevant animal model. This study provides a valuable resource for the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its history is important for understanding the evolution of medicine and public health. The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was the longest and most severe plague epidemic in history, and it is often associated with the Black Death (1347–1353). However, the role of human ectoparasites, such as fleas, in the spread of plague during the Second Pandemic has been controversial. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites fits the mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for our understanding of the history of plague and the evolution of medicine and public health.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important and least understood aspects of animal biology. It is also a key factor in the rise of complex cognition. This study provides the most comprehensive reconstruction of the evolution of brain size in amniotes, the group that includes birds and mammals. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell polarity. However, the mechanism by which it disassembles actin filaments is still unclear. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF/cofilin in a variety of cellular processes. They also suggest that the mechanical properties of the environment in which ADF/cofilin acts are critical determinants of its activity. Our findings have implications for our understanding of ADF/cofilin’s role in a wide range of cellular processes, as well as in the design of new drugs.

This study provides evidence that the effects of glucose and fructose on brain and behavior are quite different. These findings have implications for our understanding of the effects of sugar on the brain and body, and may help to explain the differences in the effects of these two simple sugars on health and disease.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history and a unique genetic structure. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian ancestry, with a limited contribution of European and Middle Eastern ancestry. The genetic structure of the population is also influenced by geography, and the genetic diversity is not homogeneous across the island. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar, and they suggest that the island was settled by multiple waves of people, and that the genetic diversity is not homogeneous across the island. These results are important for understanding the origin of the Malagasy people, and for understanding the diversity of human populations in the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a large-scale experiment, with more than 800,000 people, and it is the first to show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This work has implications for our understanding of the role of social media in our lives, and it suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

This study demonstrates that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on the rate of protein synthesis. This finding has implications for the interpretation of experiments that use mRNA sequences with Ψ in the coding region, as well as for the design of new therapeutics that target mRNA sequences.

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the development of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a long-standing and unresolved puzzle. We show that the evolution of aquatic mammals toward a size attractor of ∼500 kg is driven by the energetic demands of the aquatic environment. This result is consistent with the hypothesis that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a consequence of the aquatic environment, rather than a release from size constraints.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, at least in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

This study demonstrates that the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor for the detection of surfaces. This is an important finding because it suggests that the pili are not only used for the initial attachment to a surface, but also for the detection of the presence of the surface, which is a key step in the process of colonization.

We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the quality of global surface water resources. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is based on the analysis of 838 peer-reviewed studies. Our results show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the quality of global surface water resources.

This study provides evidence of the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the potential for the virus to circulate in this species. The findings have implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a One Health approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide public health crisis. The disease is thought to be driven by chronic inflammation, but the mechanisms involved are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric forms of amyloid-β (Aβ) are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the initiation of an inflammatory response in neurons, which is a key event in the pathogenesis of AD. Our findings provide a new perspective on the disease, and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the study of the evolution of animal husbandry and the development of the domestic animal economy. The results of our study show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world is from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel. This finding has implications for the study of the evolution of animal husbandry in the ancient Near East and for the study of the development of the domestic animal economy in Europe.

This paper is about the folding of proteins, and it is about the nature of the protein folding process. It is about the structure of proteins, and it is about the nature of the protein structure. It is about the nature of the protein, and it is about the nature of the protein folding.

We describe the discovery of a previously unknown role for the RppH pyrophosphohydrolase in the decapping of Np4-capped RNAs, which are abundant in response to stress. This enzyme, which is inactivated by disulfide stress, is able to recognize and deprotect Np4-capped RNAs, but only if the terminal nucleotide is a monophosphate. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the mechanisms by which bacteria respond to stress, and it may also have implications for the development of new antibacterial strategies.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of severe complications, such as lymphopenia, which is a major risk factor for sepsis-associated mortality. In this study, we show that arginine, a major amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is more effective than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. We provide a global census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and we highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a material of great interest for quantum applications. However, it is brittle and, therefore, difficult to process. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This opens up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

This study describes the structure and antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide. It also describes the mode of action of this peptide against plant fungal pathogens. This work provides a basis for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is the site of the most intimate interactions between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that these contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is consistent with the effects of mutations in VWF and may explain the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease. The results also suggest that the on-rate of VWF binding to platelets is faster than previously thought. This is important for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF and for developing new therapies for von Willebrand disease. (Read more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to study the impact of viruses on human health. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, and we find that viruses are associated with a wide range of diseases. This study will enable future studies to investigate the role of viruses in human health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is mainly due to the lack of observational capability to simultaneously monitor the diurnal evolution of aerosols and clouds. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to monitor the diurnal evolution of aerosols and clouds. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of intense debate for more than a century. The temperature inferred from the isotopic record of the oceans is in broad agreement with the hypothesis that the temperature of Earth’s surface has decreased over geological time. However, this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic record, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method by which to assess the temperature history inferred from the isotopic record, and demonstrate that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are responsible for the regulation of ion flow. The pore gates of ion channels are the main sites of ion conduction and are also the sites of regulation. The pore gates of K+ channels are commonly composed of two gates, one for fast activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation. The BK channel is a large-conductance calcium-activated K+ channel that lacks a classic activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels and may help in the development of new drugs. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, and the development of new treatments is urgently needed. One of the major challenges in the fight against malaria is the understanding of the process of invasion of the red blood cell by the parasite. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the red blood cell surface and that this interaction leads to changes in the biophysical properties of the red cell membrane. These changes are critical for the invasion process and suggest that the parasite primes the red blood cell surface, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This is a major step forward in our understanding of this process. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a material of great interest for quantum applications. However, it is brittle and, therefore, difficult to process. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This opens up opportunities for tailoring its properties for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

This study provides evidence that low ambient humidity impairs host defense against influenza infection, and that this effect is mediated, at least in part, by the host response to influenza infection. These findings have implications for the development of effective strategies to combat seasonal influenza, and may also be relevant to the development of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection.
We show that the brain is able to recognize the structure of sentences, and that this structure is not only hierarchical, but also that it can be represented in terms of phrases.

We show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are not only similar at the protein level but also in their regulation. This is a common feature in vertebrates, which have redundant genes that are regulated in a similar way. This may be important for the regulation of other redundant genes in the body.
This study provides a detailed description of the brain circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a key process in the functioning of the world’s ecosystems. However, the use of free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria as biofertilizers is limited by the lack of a sustainable way to control the timing and specificity of the process. Here, we describe the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a sustainable synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The results from our analysis suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. The results also suggest that the program may have contributed to sustainable forest management. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that the web of a spider is a hyperacute acoustic antenna that can sense the motion of air particles, which is better than the acoustic responsivity of the eardrum of the spider. This allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its web according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying acoustic flow detection and manipulation.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic, and the need for a vaccine is urgent. We report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response in mice. This protein can be used to design a VLP vaccine, which is a promising approach for the development of a vaccine that can be manufactured at a large scale.

We report on the identification of a ligand for the ALK/Ltk receptor tyrosine kinase family, which is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study provides a molecular basis for the involvement of ALK/Ltk in the development of neural crest-derived tissues and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for multiple pandemics. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period in Eurasia have provided insights into its evolution and ecology, but the number of genomes is too small to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which allowed us to explore correlations between temporal, geographical, and genetic distance. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a unique perspective on the origins of plague and its impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The fate of crop production on grassland-derived Mollisols is a critical question in the context of climate change. We show that the management of annual cropping systems on these soils can have a significant impact on soil organic carbon (SOC) storage. We also show that the management of perennial grasslands can have a significant impact on SOC storage, and that this impact is greater than that of annual cropping systems. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

We provide a comprehensive assessment of the risk of spillover of novel viruses to humans, using data from a large-scale virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. We prioritize the highest-risk viruses for further investigation and provide a publicly accessible platform for the community to contribute to the ongoing refinement of the risk assessment. Our work provides a foundation for the development of strategies to prevent and control future outbreaks of zoonotic viruses.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of the nectar is often an important cue for pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie the production of the color are poorly understood. Here, we describe the first nectar alkaloid of Nesocodon mauritianus, a blood-red nectar that is attractive to the gecko pollinators of this species. We also identify a red nectar alkaloid in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae, and provide evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction.

We present a study of the genetic structure of the population in Europe during the Early Medieval period. We show that the genetic structure of the population in Europe during the Early Medieval period is very complex, and that it is difficult to identify a single wave of immigration from outside the continent. In addition, we show that the genetic structure of the population in Europe during the Early Medieval period is very complex, and that it is difficult to identify a single wave of immigration from outside the continent.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of MERS-CoV and the origin of bat coronaviruses to humans. They also provide a basis for the development of strategies to prevent and control future

This study demonstrates the feasibility of using metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which was detected early in the course of an outbreak. Our study also highlights the importance of mNGS in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, as it can be used to rapidly identify pathogens of public health importance. This study provides a blueprint for mNGS-based pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, which can be used to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This information can be used to deploy rapid public health response. This study also demonstrates the feasibility of using mNGS in resource-scarce settings, which can be used to develop and deploy mNGS-based pathogen surveillance in other settings.

This study provides a detailed analysis of the processivity and stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme is not as stable as previously thought and is more similar to the processivity factor (PF) holoenzyme from S. cerevisiae. This finding has implications for the replication of the lagging strand in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study also provides a foundation for future studies to understand the role of pol δ stability in the replication of the lagging strand.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, it has been difficult to reconstitute the properties of the RNA world. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. This polymerase can replicate RNA, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be applied to other cities and to other types of urban change. We hope that it will be useful to urban geographers and urban sociologists.

This study shows that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody against interleukin 6, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected to provide a new treatment strategy for the clinical treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to control copper levels in the environment is important for their health and survival. Here we describe the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties.

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) mineral, and the rock in which it is found is a sedimentary mudstone. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock is a first for the inner martian highlands. The tridymite is cogenetic with other minerals in the rock, and the rock is a product of a single event, such as a volcanic eruption.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals, but the geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees, and that these strategies are changing in response to the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in inflammatory bowel disease, but the role of these cells in the pathogenesis of the disease is unclear. Here, we show that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis, and that they are required for the development of a subset of Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important for the development of the disease and may be important therapeutic targets.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and develop therapeutics.

This study provides a unique example of a pathogen using a host protein to alter the gut microbiota of its vector, which in turn influences the pathogen’s ability to colonize the vector. This study also provides a model for understanding the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of their vector, which may be important for understanding the ecology of vector-borne diseases.

Birds are one of the most successful animal groups, and the origin of flight is one of the most debated topics in evolutionary biology. Here, we describe a new basal bird from the Early Cretaceous of China, which adds important information about the origin of flight and the evolution of the avian tail.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that the water vapor in the stratosphere increases with the temperature in the troposphere, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are green. The color of a vertebrate is determined by the absorption spectrum of its pigments, which are distributed in the skin, blood, and bones. In this study, we describe a new class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a molecule that is responsible for the green color of plants. We show that these proteins are responsible for the green color of anurans, and that they have evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of vertebrates. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of green color in vertebrates, and open new avenues for the study of the evolution of color in vertebrates. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is increased in breast cancer stem cells, and ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. This paper presents a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface, followed by peptide mass fingerprinting. The method is noninvasive and does not require the use of chemicals or solvents. The method is also highly sensitive, allowing the identification of the animal origin of a single parchment sample. The results of this study suggest that the use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment was not as widespread as previously thought.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb zircon dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including cancer, metabolism, and circadian rhythm. In this study, we report the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific deletion of RORα (RORαΔIEC) and its role in maintaining intestinal homeostasis. We found that RORα is crucial for attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity in IECs, which is important for the control of intestinal inflammation. Our results provide insights into the epigenetic regulation of RORα and its role in intestinal inflammation, which could be beneficial for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 in complex with the human receptor ACE2. We find that the receptor binds to the spike with high affinity, and that the receptor-binding domain of the spike is highly flexible. We also find that the spike glycoprotein contains a number of mutations, some of which are associated with increased infectivity. Our results provide insights into the structure and function of the spike glycoprotein, and may help to explain the increased infectivity of some of the currently circulating variants.

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in 2020, the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are of great importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest to physicists, who study the properties of matter under pressure. We show that the chemical properties of atoms change under pressure, and we provide a quantitative description of this change.

We show that the effects of fire on climate are more complex than previously thought. We find that human demography, rather than climate, is the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity. This has implications for the future of the carbon cycle, as well as for the role of fire in ecosystem functioning.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of symbiosis. It shows that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a key factor in the maintenance of the mutualism. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting carbon and energy to maintain a stable symbiont population. This glycan-dependent regulation of symbiont numbers is likely to be a general feature of symbioses in which the host provides nutrients to its symbionts, and the catabolism of these nutrients is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis.

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We show that the method can be applied to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We show that the method can be used to identify topics in text, to identify the gender bias of topics, and to compare the gender bias of topics to the gender bias of the data. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that our method will be of interest to researchers in many fields, including psychology, sociology, criminology, and medicine. The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. View Full-Text

Asteroids are a group of marine invertebrates that are of economic and ecological importance. They are the most abundant group of animals on the sea floor and are the primary food source for a variety of predators, including sea otters, sea lions, and sea stars. In the past 2 y, a disease has been observed in a number of species of asteroids, leading to rapid mortality. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is present in the environment.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. We have identified IL1RAP (IL1R3) as a target for treatment of AML, and we have developed an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and of achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity. This antibody is effective in suppressing the growth of AML cells in vitro and in vivo, and it is well tolerated in mice. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history and a unique genetic structure. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian ancestry, with a limited contribution of European and Middle Eastern ancestry. The genetic structure of the population is also influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce genetic structure in the population. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar and the settlement of the island. They also provide a better understanding of the genetic structure of the human population, which is important for the study of human evolution. They also provide a better understanding of the genetic structure of the human population, which is important for the study of human evolution. View Full-Text

This work describes a dual-function RNA that encodes a protein and also forms a small RNA that regulates the expression of genes involved in carbon utilization. The protein is membrane-associated and increases the activity of a glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. The RNA is located in the cytoplasm and forms a complex with the A. uvarum tRNA(Gln) and the A. uvarum and E. coli tRNA(Glu). The RNA base-pairs with the A. uvarum tRNA(Glu) and the E. coli tRNA(Glu), and also with the E. coli mRNA. The RNA base-pairing interferes with the ability of the A. uvarum RNA to repress the expression of cadA and galE. The RNA also base-pairs with the E. coli mRNA, and the protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress the expression of the E. coli genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their knowledge is critical to monitor and manage agricultural production. However, the vast majority of crop experts are not part of the agricultural industry, and their knowledge is not captured in official statistics. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is the primary source of information on crop status, is biased by the subjective nature of the crop experts, and that this bias can be quantified and corrected. We propose a quantitative crop condition index based on the survey data, which can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of harnessing the power of the “people as sensors” network to monitor and manage agricultural production.

Language is a highly complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The response of soil respiration to warming is a key question in ecology and climate science. However, the results from the vast majority of studies are contradictory, and the global-scale response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the history of life, and the molecular signature of this transition is still poorly understood. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism leads to a relaxation of selection on the plastid genome, which is linked to the loss of function. Our results provide a framework for understanding the molecular evolution of the plastid genome during the transition from autotrophy to parasitism.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the result of a combination of natural and anthropogenic factors. However, the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the drought risk in this region is difficult to quantify, given the small regional scale. Here, we use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in the region. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for the development of adaptation strategies in the region.
